subject: Re: [junit] Where am I going wrong?
msgSnippet: I have lost the context of the test code... The comment I wrote was just to clear up the fog with the immutable string business. ... -- Jason Rogers Where
messageBody:
I have lost the context of the test code... The comment I wrote was just
to clear up the fog with the immutable string business.

On Mon, 2004-04-05 at 14:52, Chris Dollin wrote:
> On Monday 05 April 2004 10:30, Jason Rogers wrote:
> > On Mon, 2004-04-05 at 12:52, Chris Dollin wrote:
> > > On Friday 02 April 2004 23:09, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > > > mcgqa wrote:
> > > > > */
> > > > > public void testRegisterUser() {
> > > > > dupLoginId = newLoginId;
> > >
> > > [both variables are Strings]
> > >
> > > > This line is probably wrong. I assume you want dupLoginId to be a
> > > > "snapshot" of newLoginId. Right now, they refer to the same physical
> > > > string, so a change through one reference will be seen through the
> > > > second reference.
> > >
> > > Strings are immutable, so I don't see that this can happen. What am I
> > > missing?
> >
> > Sounds like you need to read up on references...
>
> Thank you, but that will not be necessary. I just need my brain defogging.
>
> Is the claim that the original code depends on the reference value of the
> login ids rather than their content? If that were so, I'd understand the
> problem, but I can't see such a dependence.
>
> And looking at the code - dupLoginId will be the empty string at the
> beginning of each test, because it's an instance variable; the assignment
> is useless because the instance variable evaporates when the test its
> assigned in terminates, yes? Shouldn't the test for duplicate logins be
> like
>
> testDuplicateLogins()
> login( "me" );
> try { login( "me" ); fail( "oops, duplicate login not detected" ); }
> catch (DuplicateLoginException e) { pass(); }
>
> (flavour to taste)?
--
Jason Rogers

"Where there is no vision, the people perish..."
Bible, Proverbs 29:18
